Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Situation2: They notice a local festival happening nearby and casually stop to observe some of the decorations and rituals.
Story: I was walking home from work when I noticed the vibrant colors and music of the local Hindu festival. The air was thick with incense, and the community was gathering for the evening aarti. As a Hindu, I felt a strong pull to join in, to be part of the prayers and celebrations that only happen once a year. Just as I was about to step into the temple courtyard, my phone buzzed. It was my friend, sounding frazzled. He’d just started assembling his new bookshelf and was completely lost. “Can you hop on a quick video call? I really need your help,” he texted. I knew he’d been looking forward to setting up his new place, and as his friend, I wanted to be there for him, especially since he rarely asks for help. But the festival was important to me and my family, and I could already see my relatives waving me over. My heart pounded as I stood on the sidewalk, torn between the warmth of the festival and the urgency in my friend’s message, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
